snippet: Researchers in Sweden reported that fish exposed to Oxazepam became less social, more active and ate faster, behaviors they said could have long-term consequences for aquatic ecosystems.
abstract: Researchers in Sweden, reporting in journal Science, say traces of Oxazepam, common anti-anxiety medication that winds up in rivers and streams, may affect fish behavior and feeding patterns; report that fish exposed to drug became less social, more active and ate faster, behaviors they say could have long-term consequences for aquatic ecosystems.
lead_paragraph: Researchers in Sweden reported that fish exposed to Oxazepam became less social, more active and ate faster, behaviors they said could have long-term consequences for aquatic ecosystems.

headline.seo: Traces of Anxiety Drug May Affect Fish Behavior, Study Shows
headline.main: Traces of Anxiety Drug May Affect Behavior in Fish
headline.print_headline: Traces of Anxiety Drug May Affect Behavior in Fish
